et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}ordre{/it}, from Medieval Latin & Latin; Medieval Latin {it}ordin-, ordo{/it} ecclesiastical order, from Latin, arrangement, group, class; akin to Latin {it}ordiri{/it} to lay the warp, begin
shortdef: a group of people united in a formal way: such as
a community under a religious rule; especially : one requiring members to take solemn vows

dt.t: The books are {wi}ordered{/wi} alphabetically by author.
They {wi}ordered{/wi} everyone out of the house.

dt: {bc}to command to go or come to a specified place

dt.t: I {wi}ordered{/wi} the books from the company's website.
a renascence of the spirit that {wi}orders{/wi} and controls
Be sure to {wi}order{/wi} before it's too late.

pt: {sc}order{/sc} {sc}arrange{/sc} {sc}marshal{/sc} {sc}organize{/sc} {sc}systematize{/sc} {sc}methodize{/sc} mean to put persons or things into their proper places in relation to each other. {sc}order{/sc} suggests a straightening out so as to eliminate confusion.
{sc}arrange{/sc} implies a setting in sequence, relationship, or adjustment.
{sc}marshal{/sc} suggests gathering and arranging in preparation for a particular operation or effective use.
{sc}organize{/sc} implies arranging so that the whole aggregate works as a unit with each element having a proper function.
{sc}systematize{/sc} implies arranging according to a predetermined scheme.
{sc}methodize{/sc} suggests imposing an orderly procedure rather than a fixed scheme.

shortdef: to give an order to : command

dt: {bc}authoritative orders or instructions especially to set out on or as if on a march

dt.t: The Alpharetta City Council has approved a $2.9 million {wi}change order{/wi} for the Rucker Road Corridor improvement project, reflecting Roswell's share of the project cost.

dt.t: During the frequent riots of the Lindsay era, police often under- or overreacted—while various officials, including the mayor's civilian aides, issued orders and {wi}counterorders{/wi}, exacerbating the disorder.
